## PHYSICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 298, 329, 314]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 390, 388, 407]]<|/det|>
## READ THESE INSTRUCTIONS FIRST  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 416, 718, 432]]<|/det|>
Write your Centre number, candidate number and name on all the work you hand in.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 432, 320, 446]]<|/det|>
Write in dark blue or black pen.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 446, 502, 461]]<|/det|>
You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 460, 504, 475]]<|/det|>
Do not use staples, paper clips, glue or correction fluid.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 475, 380, 490]]<|/det|>
DO NOT WRITE IN ANY BARCODES.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 501, 255, 515]]<|/det|>
Answer all questions.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 515, 361, 530]]<|/det|>
Electronic calculators may be used.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 530, 767, 546]]<|/det|>
You may lose marks if you do not show your working or if you do not use appropriate units.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 555, 604, 570]]<|/det|>
At the end of the examination, fasten all your work securely together.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 570, 759, 585]]<|/det|>
The number of marks is given in brackets [ ] at the end of each question or part question.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 92, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
A student is determining the acceleration of free fall \(g\) using a pendulum. Fig. 1.1 shows the pendulum. Fig. 1.2 shows one complete oscillation of the pendulum.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[175, 119, 831, 330]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[265, 342, 334, 361]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 1.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[656, 342, 728, 361]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 1.2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 373, 146, 392]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 373, 460, 392]]<|/det|>
On Fig. 1.1, measure the distance \(d\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[556, 403, 920, 422]]<|/det|>
<form>d = .................................................... $cm$ [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 435, 146, 454]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 435, 447, 454]]<|/det|>
Fig. 1.1 is drawn \(1 / 10^{\text{th}}\) actual size.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 466, 181, 485]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 466, 895, 485]]<|/det|>
Calculate the actual distance \(D\) from the bottom of the clamp to the centre of the bob.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[554, 511, 920, 530]]<|/det|>
<form>D = .................................................... $cm$ [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 543, 920, 577]]<|/det|>
The student displaces the bob slightly and releases it so that it swings. He measures the time \(t\) for 10 complete oscillations. The time \(t\) is shown on the stopwatch in Fig. 1.3.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[410, 588, 583, 720]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 733, 534, 752]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 1.3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 765, 180, 784]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 765, 522, 784]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[561, 795, 920, 814]]<|/det|>
<form>t = ............................................................ [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 826, 180, 845]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 826, 920, 860]]<|/det|>
Calculate the period \(T\) of the pendulum. The period is the time for one complete oscillation.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[559, 898, 920, 917]]<|/det|>
<form>T = ............................................................ [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 72, 180, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(iv)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 71, 308, 89]]<|/det|>
Calculate \(T^2\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[544, 116, 920, 137]]<|/det|>
<form>\(T^2 =\) ........................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 149, 181, 168]]<|/det|>
<label>(v)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[195, 147, 735, 170]]<|/det|>
Calculate the acceleration of free fall \(g\) using the equation \(g = \frac{20}{T^2}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[556, 227, 920, 245]]<|/det|>
<form>g = ................................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 257, 146, 275]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 256, 920, 291]]<|/det|>
The student adjusts the pendulum until the distance \(D\) measured to the centre of the bob is \(100.0 \text{cm}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 303, 641, 323]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[556, 330, 776, 350]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[791, 330, 918, 350]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 96, 91]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 541, 91]]<|/det|> A student is determining the focal length \(f\) of a lens. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 103, 364, 121]]<|/det|> Fig. 3.1 shows the apparatus. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[107, 139, 203, 156]]<|/det|> illuminated <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[139, 149, 895, 242]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 259, 532, 278]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 290, 146, 308]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 289, 828, 308]]<|/det|> The student places the screen a distance \(D = 70.0 \text{cm}\) from the illuminated object. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 320, 920, 355]]<|/det|> He places the lens close to the screen and moves the lens slowly away from the screen until a clearly focused image is formed on the screen. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 367, 865, 386]]<|/det|> He measures the distance \(u\) between the centre of the lens and the illuminated object. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 399, 774, 416]]<|/det|> He measures the distance \(v\) between the centre of the lens and the screen. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 429, 868, 448]]<|/det|> He repeats the procedure using values for \(D\) of \(75.0 \text{cm}, 80.0 \text{cm}, 85.0 \text{cm}\) and \(90.0 \text{cm}\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 460, 463, 479]]<|/det|> The readings are shown in Table 3.1. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 491, 631, 510]]<|/det|> Calculate, and record in Table 3.1, \(uv\) for each value of \(D\). <|ref|>table_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[457, 521, 539, 540]]<|/det|> Table 3.1 <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[304, 549, 692, 734]]<|/det|>
\(D/\text{cm}\)\(u/\text{cm}\)\(v/\text{cm}\)\(uv/\text{cm}^2\)
70.022.048.4
75.020.754.5
80.020.060.0
85.019.565.8
90.019.071.2
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 736, 920, 754]]<|/det|> [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 148, 88]]<|/det|>

<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 920, 135]]<|/det|>
A student is investigating the effect of double-walled insulation on the rate of cooling of hot water in a copper container. The student places the copper container inside a larger metal container. He is investigating the effect of the size of the air gap between the copper container and larger metal containers.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 149, 920, 182]]<|/det|>
Plan an experiment to investigate the effect of the size of the air gap between the copper container and larger metal containers on the rate of cooling of hot water.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 197, 420, 214]]<|/det|>
The following apparatus is available:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 228, 314, 244]]<|/det|>
a copper container

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 247, 883, 263]]<|/det|>
a number of metal containers of different diameters (all larger than the copper container)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 268, 281, 283]]<|/det|>
a thermometer

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 288, 260, 303]]<|/det|>
a stopwatch

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 308, 331, 324]]<|/det|>
a measuring cylinder

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 329, 336, 344]]<|/det|>
a supply of hot water.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 359, 907, 375]]<|/det|>
You can also use other apparatus and materials that are usually available in a school laboratory.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 390, 324, 406]]<|/det|>
In your plan, you should:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 420, 133, 438]]<|/det|>
<label>•</label>

state the key variables that you would control

<label>•</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 483, 920, 515]]<|/det|>
draw a table, or tables, with column headings, to show how you would display your readings (you are not required to enter any readings in the table)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 530, 133, 548]]<|/det|>
<label>•</label>

To avoid the issue of disclosure of answer- related information to candidates, all copyright acknowledgements are reproduced online in the Cambridge International Examinations Copyright Acknowledgements Booklet. This is produced for each series of examinations and is freely available to download at www.cie.org.uk after the live examination series.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 914, 917, 939]]<|/det|>
Cambridge International Examinations is part of the Cambridge Assessment Group. Cambridge Assessment is the brand name of University of Cambridge Local Examinations Syndicate (UCLES), which is itself a department of the University of Cambridge.
